en: A castle that turns water into wine... If the vine is currently the main activity of the village, it is also the pride of the people of Saint-Jean. The water tower of Saint-Jean-de-Serres, decorated on the initiative of the village's winegrowers, can testify to this with these immense scenes inspired by the work of the vine and wine, painted at its summit. A true emblem of the local wines, this atypical work also allows the commune to be seen from afar. The old mill But the official communal symbol is the old mill of Saint-Jean-de-Serres, situated to the north of the village along the D907 on a neighbouring hill overlooking the village. Small openings under the roof suggest that the current owner transformed it into a dovecote. 11th century church The village is wrapped around its 11th century Romanesque church. The foundations would date from the 9th or 10th century according to the sources. And as is often the case in the region, the religious building has had to face numerous destructions during the wars of religion. Around 1559, Protestantism is little emulated in the village, most of the inhabitants remain Catholics. But the geographical position of Saint-Jean-de-Serres, 11 km from Anduze, exposed it to the incursions of the "heretics" and the village could not escape the devastation in 1575. Promulgated in 1598, the Edict of Nantes offered a period of truce, which allowed the reconstruction of the church to begin. This will be completed around 1663. But shortly afterwards, in 1685, the revocation of the Edict of Nantes by Louis XIV forced the Protestants into hiding, the temples were destroyed and bastions were built to control the territory. In 1702-1704, the Camisards revolted violently against the Catholics and the royal power. Saint-Jean-de-Serres is besieged by the Camisards in 1703, the surroundings are ravaged but the villagers manage to protect the church.
fr: Un château qui change l'eau en vin... Si la vigne est actuellement la principale activité du village, elle fait également la fierté des saint-jeannaises et des saint-jeannais. Le château d'eau de Saint-Jean-de-Serres, décoré à l'initiative des vignerons du village, peut en témoigner avec ces immenses scènes inspirées du travail de la vigne et du vin, peintes à son sommet. Véritable emblème des vins du cru, cet ouvrage atypique permet d'ailleurs de repérer la commune de loin. L'ancien moulin Mais le symbole communal officiel, c'est le l'ancien moulin de Saint-Jean-de-Serres, situé au Nord du village le long de la D907 sur une colline voisine surplombant le village. De petites ouvertures placées sous le toit laisse présumer que le propriétaire actuel l'a transformé en pigeonnier. Eglise du XIe siècle Le village s’enroule autour de son église romane du XIe siècle. Les fondations daterait du IXe ou Xe siècle selon les sources. Et comme souvent dans la région, l'édifice religieux a du faire face à de nombreuses destructions pendant les guerres de religion. Vers 1559, le protestantisme fait peu d’émules dans le village, la majeure partie des habitants reste catholiques. Mais la position géographique de Saint-Jean-de-Serres à 11 km d’Anduze l’expose aux incursions des « hérétiques » et le village ne peut échapper à la dévastation en 1575.Promulgué en 1598, l'Edit de Nantes offre une période de trêve, ce qui permet d'entamer la reconstruction de l'Eglise. Celle-ci s’achèvera vers 1663. Mais peu de temps après, en 1685, la révocation de l’édit de Nantes par louis XIV oblige les protestants à entrer dans la clandestinité, les temples sont détruits, des bastions sont construits pour le contrôle du territoire. En 1702-1704, les Camisards se révoltent violemment contre les catholiques et le pouvoir royal. Saint-Jean-de-Serres est assiégé par les camisards en 1703, les environs sont ravagés mais les villageois réussissent à protéger l’église.

hasBeenCreatedBy.schema:legalName: OFFICE DE TOURISME CEVENNES GRAND SUD

hasBeenPublishedBy.schema:logo: https://www.tourismegard.com/Portals/2/Market-place/Le portail des pros du tourisme du Gard_fichiers/logo-Gard-Tourisme.jpg

en:
A castle that turns water into wine... If the vine is currently the main activity of the village, it is also the pride of the people of Saint-Jean-de-Serres. The water tower of Saint-Jean-de-Serres, decorated on the initiative of the winegrowers of the village, can testify to this with these immense scenes inspired by the work of the vine and the wine, painted on its top. A true emblem of the wines of the region, this atypical structure allows the village to be identified from afar.
The old millBut the official communal symbol is the old mill of Saint-Jean-de-Serres, located north of the village along the D907 on a nearby hill overlooking the village. Small openings under the roof suggest that the current owner has transformed it into a dovecote.
11th century church
The village revolves around its 11th century Romanesque church. The foundations date from the 9th or 10th century according to the sources. And as is often the case in the region, the religious building had to face numerous destructions during the religious wars. Around 1559, the Protestantism made few emulators in the village, the major part of the inhabitants remained catholic. But the geographical position of Saint-Jean-de-Serres at 11 km from Anduze exposes it to the incursions of the "heretics" and the village cannot escape the devastation in 1575. Promulgated in 1598, the Edict of Nantes offers a period of truce, which makes it possible to start the rebuilding of the Church. This was completed around 1663. But shortly after, in 1685, the revocation of the Edict of Nantes by Louis XIV forced the Protestants to go underground, the temples were destroyed, and bastions were built to control the territory. In 1702-1704, the Camisards violently revolted against the Catholics and the royal power. Saint-Jean-de-Serres was besieged by the Camisards in 1703, the surroundings were ravaged but the villagers managed to protect the church.

De petites ouvertures placées sous le toit laisse présumer que le propriétaire actuel l'a transformé en pigeonnier.
